item.title:
Probably the tweet that'll get me cancelled, but: if publishers start to pay reviewers, they'll just pass that cost on to authors in the form of increased APCs.
Plus a profit margin and handling fee.
If anything, it will take money *out* of research budgets. https://t.co/WuDGCRVphd
item.description:

item.title:
Keep in mind, companies cannot simply venmo random folks money. Can you imagine the extra bureaucracy involved in peer review, if now for every review you had to sign a payment contract?
Guess who will ultimately pay for that extra paperwork?
item.description:

item.title:
"It's fine, I review so much I would still have a net positive"
Are you sure? Not every reviewed manuscript is published; I reckon the average is over 4 reviews per published paper. Add handling costs, and you're looking at 5 ~ 6 reviews per submitted paper, just to break even.
item.description:
"It's fine, I review so much I would still have a net positive"
Are you sure? Not every reviewed manuscript is published; I reckon the average is over 4 reviews per published paper. Add handling costs, and you're looking at 5 ~ 6 reviews per submitted paper, just to break even.
item.content:encoded: "It's fine, I review so much I would still have a net positive" Are you sure? Not every reviewed manuscript is published; I reckon the average is over 4 reviews per published paper. Add handling costs, and you're looking at 5 ~ 6 reviews per submitted paper, just to break even.

item.title:
If you don't want to support for-profit publishers, by all means don't review for them and don't submit to their journals.
But if you expect others to peer review your work while not returning the favor, well, the only ones you're "sticking it to" are your fellow academics.
